qas.question: What specific ocean temperature conditions effect Tuvalu?
Which effect causes increases in sea storms like cyclones?
What is the usual amount of rainfall per month on Tuvalu?
What did a drought in 2011 cause on Funafuti?

context: Tuvalu experiences the effects of <a0_0>El Niño and La Niña<a0_0/> caused by changes in ocean temperatures in the equatorial and central Pacific. <a1_0>El Niño<a1_0/> effects increase the chances of tropical storms and cyclones, while <a2_0>La Niña<a2_0/> effects increase the chances of drought. Typically the islands of Tuvalu receive between <a3_0>200 to 400 mm<a3_0/> (8 to 16 in) of rainfall per month. However, in 2011 a weak La Niña effect caused a drought by cooling the surface of the sea around Tuvalu. A state of emergency was declared on 28 September 2011; with <a4_0>rationing of fresh-water<a4_0/> on the islands of Funafuti and Nukulaelae. Households on Funafuti and Nukulaelae were restricted to two buckets of fresh water per day (40 litres).
